bestBHT.bht: The Son, in contrast to mortal and sinful men, did not need to offer sacrifices for His own sin. Having been consecrated as a perfected priest through His perfect sacrifice, He stands alone as the only one who sustains this office. He is the ultimate High Priest who saves to the uttermost, making salvation complete. Unlike the inefficiency of the Levitical priests, Christ is sinless and perfectly equipped to meet our needs, having offered Himself as a perfect sacrifice. His priestly ministry is superior to theirs, being continuous and unchanging, and He remains a priest forever.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: He needed not, as they, to offer FOR HIS OWN SIN; and being now exempt from death and 'perfected for evermore,' He needs not to REPEAT His sacrifice.
Consecrated as a perfected priest by His perfected sacrifice, and consequent anointing and exaltation to the right hand of the Father.
Albert Barnes: He stands alone. In that office he had no predecessor, and has no one to succeed him. In this respect he was without father, mother, or descent - and he stands in lonely majesty as the only one who sustains the office."
The great High Priest of the Christian profession is the only perfect priest... his office needs no change.

Christ saves to the uttermost. He makes the salvation complete... as far as we can trace the departing soul when it goes into the dark valley, we receive the same assurance; and why should we doubt that the same grace is bestowed further onward, and that he saves 'to the uttermost'?
Marvin Vincent: The law constitutes weak men high priests. God's sworn declaration constitutes a son, perfected forevermore.
Again the high-priesthood is bound up with sonship.
Christ's ministry is superior to that of the Levitical priests as he himself is superior to them.
John Calvin: Since the law makes no real priests, the defect must by some other means be remedied.
Christ was made a priest, being not of the common order of men, but the Son of God, subject to no defect, but adorned and endowed with the highest perfection.
God, being not satisfied with the priesthood of the law, designed to constitute a better priesthood.
Philip Schaff: They were mortal, sinful men, and therefore were an inefficient priesthood; their expiations, their intercessions, their benedictions, all had the character of weakness, and as such they were not fit to meet our needs.

'Perfected' or 'made perfect' (not 'consecrated') 'for evermore;' it is the same word as is used in chap. Hebrews 2:10, 'made perfect through suffering;' and in Hebrews 5:9, 'having been made perfect.'
This condition is continuous and unchanging, forming a contrast to the condition of the priests of the Law.
Archibald T. Robertson: Perfected (τετελειωμενον). The process (Hebrews 2:10) was now complete.
We demand a permanent high priest who is sinless and perfectly equipped by divine appointment and human experience.
With the perfect offering of himself as a sacrifice.
John Gill: Every word has an emphasis on it, and shows the difference between Christ and these priests.
Christ, though a man, yet he is not mere man; he is the Son of God, and as such opposed to men.
The law made men priests that did not continue, but Christ is a priest for evermore, and absolutely, perfect.
John Wesley: The law maketh men high priests that have infirmity.
But the oath which was since the law... Maketh the son, who is consecrated for ever.
Who being now free, both from sin and death, from natural and moral infirmity, remaineth a priest for ever.

He is the ultimate High Priest who saves to the uttermost, making salvation complete. Unlike the inefficiency of the Levitical priests, Christ is sinless and perfectly equipped to meet our needs. The Son, in contrast to mortal and sinful men, did not need to offer sacrifices for His own sin. Having been consecrated as a perfected priest through His perfect sacrifice, He stands alone as the only one who sustains this office. He is the ultimate High Priest who saves to the uttermost, making salvation complete. Unlike the inefficiency of the Levitical priests, Christ is sinless and thoroughly equipped to meet our needs. His priestly ministry is superior to theirs, being continuous and unchanging, as He remains a priest forever.

The Son, unlike mortal men, did not need to offer sacrifices for His own sin. Consecrated as a perfect priest through His sacrifice, He stands alone, fulfilling the office in a way that needs no change. Christ, the great High Priest, saves completely and without limit. The Levitical priests were flawed and inefficient, unable to meet our needs, but Christ is sinless and perfectly equipped by divine appointment. His priesthood is superior, continuous, and unchanging, forever remaining a priest.

The Son, unlike mortal men, did not need to offer sacrifices for His own sin. Consecrated as a perfect priest through His sacrifice, He stands alone, fulfilling the office in a way that needs no change. Christ, the great High Priest, saves completely and without limit. Unlike the inefficient Levitical priests, He is sinless and perfectly equipped by divine appointment. His priesthood is superior, continuous, and unchanging, forever remaining a priest.
